title: Ads are making experience worse
text:
With the latest update, it seems the the UI people have decided to show the first email as a targeted advertisement. Having used this app for over 5 years, I am used to clicking the first email as the unread email and I have accidentally clicked the advertisement multiple occasions within the last month of this stupid update. 

Hoping someone reads my review and makes a change that will likely allow me to continue using the app. I‚Äôll give it a chance for one more year out of inertia but if the ad UI doesn‚Äôt change, bye bye outlook and I am sure lots of users will do the same.

title: I‚Äôve tried over a week working back and forth with senders
text:
I finally got one of my ‚Äúsubscribed‚Äù emails - by subscribed, I actually pay for. It‚Äôs been at least four weeks. 
I tried the useless phone help, the useless online help, I tried going into the Apple store, to which they said, it‚Äôs not getting thru MSN!
I tried writing a letter, you know USPS.
For all the people you have working there you have no one who will actually help when there‚Äôs an issue and that is very undesirable! Frankly, I wouldn‚Äôt give money again to be on MSN anything! 

The ones I‚Äôm still not getting are Doctors office updated data related.

When I read the one above, ‚Äúnot being able to delete permanently emails‚Äù - I thought, me either! I had to buy a bigger storage phone!
This is insane! 99% of my emails are total junk!
Apple checked to see if it was too full.

I have ‚Äúfocussed‚Äù folders but it‚Äôs still not going there! 
I‚Äôve been ready (a long time) to get rid of all 7 computers phones and pads over this - but we have to have them, it‚Äôs no longer optional unless we die! At 68, I‚Äôm getting too old for all the changes! 

I tell everyone, I have MSN email, I can not count on it! If you send me an email, you have to call me and tell me exactly which email it is sent from, and there is only a 50/50 chance I‚Äôll get it. Please use USPS. It‚Äôs about an 80% chance I‚Äôll get it there in a week.

title: Was so much better
text: I switched from native mail app a couple years ago and we use exchange for work email and it was great. The last year it‚Äôs gone downhill, I‚Äôve had to contact support so much that Microsoft should pay me for R&D. The spellcheck isn‚Äôt working correctly, I can‚Äôt edit emails when composing sometimes, errors sending messages, and the list goes on. I‚Äôve had a particular item that support has been working on for months. It‚Äôs just disappointing it was so much better and has gone downhill.

title: Not always smooth with iOS
text:
Update: this app is so frustrating for me that I had to come back just to move it from the stars to two stars. I forgot to mention that it is really difficult to underline, italics, or bold a word or phrase when writing an email. If you‚Äôre just reading emails and never need to send, I guess the app is fine for that. Writing emails is an exercise in frustration for me with this app!!!

The app works okay but writing emails on it using an iPhone can be very frustrating. It is trying to do its own spell check and grammar check while the iOS native spell checking is also functioning and these seem to me to interfere with each other. The same goes for when it makes ‚Äúsuggestions‚Äù about completing a word or phrase. It appears to me that it is not well integrated with same functions native to iOS. Usually I end up writing my email in a note and just copying and pasting it over. That has saved me a lot of frustration.

title: Minimal Functionality
text:
I‚Äôve had this app for years and it continues to disappoint. Why does Outlook desktop, web app, and mobile apps refuse to work together and provide users with a unified experience? It shouldn‚Äôt be this hard with a software service that‚Äôs almost as old as I am. 

Keeping my inbox organized in an automated way is nearly impossible while using this app. The rules you can apply via the web app don‚Äôt have commonality to manipulate when your emails can be moved. For example: I can‚Äôt adjust categories, flag state (except to clear it), or level of importance in the iOS app, but those are a few of the things I can build rules around in the web app to help me keep my inbox sorted. 

Its not so hard to think that once I‚Äôve read an email, I would like and file the email away in a folder based on the parameters I‚Äôve programmed unless I‚Äôve added a flag OR pinned the email. Don‚Äôt even get me started on why Outlooks logic statements only have ‚ÄúAnd‚Äù as an exception instead of or in addition to ‚ÄúOr‚Äù.  Its a very basic concept, and yet outlook lacks it entirely. Or even just a rule that can apply more than one category or change the status of flags. The only way to program these types of rules is to use the desktop app, and most people don‚Äôt even have home computers these days, so what‚Äôs the point? 

And it makes me cringe when I see so much effort put into the whole ‚Äúfocused‚Äù inbox or moving unread emails to different locations, which inevitably makes me miss emails. Outlook clearly doesn‚Äôt understand the concept of ‚Äúout of sight, out of mind‚Äù that a huge population experiences and needs to get with the neurodivergent times to provide more flexibility to keep users email organized while streamlining the visual experience so users only have to check 1 location that isn't clutter by the 50,000 emails that the users don‚Äôt have time to manually move once they‚Äôve been read.

title: Microsoft wins‚Ä¶
text: Outlook works flawlessly on both my iPad and my Android devices. It‚Äôs a godsend to have a mail client that works reliably. Thanks Microsoft, you‚Äôve come a long way in the arena of enabling cross-platform compatibility and making e-mail accessible.
